awd_abstract_narration:
This project is addressing issues - such as the environmentally-friendly manufacturing of economically-important chemicals - that are at the forefront of modern chemical synthesis, catalysis, and sustainability.  Photochemistry is the conversion of solar energy into chemical energy and is an important component of this goal. The application of photochemistry to organic synthesis has traditionally required hazardous reagents and/or high energy, ultraviolet light. In this project, Dr. Stephenson is studying the use of complexes that harvest sunlight to power chemical reactions. Importantly, this research project is being carried out in collaboration with pharmaceutical companies. This collaboration enables the rapid incorporation of the new methods into practical applications. Dr. Stephenson's research group participates in several outreach programs to engage grade school (3rd-12th grade) students, with the intention of inspiring the next generation of scientists and leaders. For example, the research team is contributing to the Females Excelling More in Mathematics, Engineering, and the Science (FEMMES) and the Michigan Math and Science Scholars (MMSS) programs at the University of Michigan. This outreach is directly engaging grade school students in a fun and supportive atmosphere, while also encouraging them to pursue a career in STEM.


With funding from the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Stephenson at the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor is studying how transiently generated electron donor-acceptor (EDA) complexes can be leveraged for the development of new methods in chemical synthesis. The rational design of visible light-active EDA complexes is possible by applying basic principles of Mulliken theory.  Such complexes are characterized by UV-Vis spectroscopy. EDA photocatalysis represents an exciting new frontier for the development of methods in organic synthesis. In this regard, methods for arene trifluoromethylation and radical aryl transpositions, for the rapid generation of molecular complexity, are being developed. Through a detailed understanding of each reaction mechanism, the developed methods are rapidly translated to industrial scale in collaboration with the AbbVie Process Research and Development team. Dr. Stephenson's research group is involved in several outreach programs that apply their expertise in synthetic chemistry to engage grade school (3rd-12th grade) students, with the intention of inspiring the next generation of scientific leaders. Dr. Stephenson's involvement in the Females Excelling More in Mathematics, Engineering, and the Science (FEMMES) and the Michigan Math and Science Scholars (MMSS) programs at the University of Michigan have allowed for the direct engagement of grade school students to teach synthetic chemistry in a fun and supportive atmosphere while also encouraging them to pursue a career in STEM.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. This project links recent advances in the activation of carboxylic acid derivatives as radical precursors with electron donor-acceptor complexes to develop new sustainable methods for photocatalysis. Many photochemical reactions which form radicals from carboxylic acids rely on catalysts derived from rare and expensive metals with bespoke ligand systems. Even when used in small amounts, the high cost of these catalysts can often be a limiting factor when scaling photochemical reactions. To address this, we have published a method which relies on simple and inexpensive organic electron donors to activate carboxylic acid derivatives as an alternative to the use of metal-based photocatalysts. Importantly, we discovered that these electron donors can facilitate efficient reactivity in substoichiometric amounts and employed them to form electron donor-acceptor complexes as distinct catalytic intermediates for radical generation. We successfully applied this approach to the development of a new and operationally simple method for the perfluoroalkylation of medicinally relevant heterocycles. Furthermore, through our studies we were able to develop a photochemical method for the alkylation of medicinally relevant heterocycles which does not rely on the need for a catalyst to facilitate the reaction. These results demonstrate that new advances in the application of electron donor-acceptor complexes to photocatalysis and the catalyst-free generation of organic radicals using visible light are well underway.

As measured by productivity, the impact of this funding can be seen in the publications and presentations that have arisen during the granting period to disseminate the results to the broader community:

  • 3 peer-reviewed publications with >75 total citations.
  • >15 presentations and posters given by undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows at local, regional and national meetings.
  • Training opportunities for >6 undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows have been facilitated by this research funding.

Broader Impacts. The full potential of free radicals in chemical synthesis has not been fully harnessed due to traditional methods of their generation and the environmental impact of the byproducts produced in the process. Visible light photocatalysis has played a crucial role in revitalizing research efforts towards mild and environmentally friendly approaches to unlock the potential of these versatile chemical species. Further to these efforts, the use of donor-acceptor complexes offers the opportunity to move toward a more sustainable approach to harnessing these valuable reactive intermediates.

The University of Michigan is a state university dedicated to educating, ground-breaking scientific research, and outreach at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. Importantly, Michigan is an institution that promotes diversity in all education areas. As part of this NSF award, we have undertaken two major efforts in this regard.

Within the framework of the Michigan Math and Science Scholars Program (MMSS), our involvement centers around coordinating and overseeing the Michigan Math Science Scholars course on Green Chemistry, Catalysis, and Solar Energy Conversion. This two-week program, held in two sessions each summer with an approximate total of 30 students, is designed to introduce a diverse group of high school students to advanced concepts in catalysis, emphasizing sustainable chemistry. As part of our educational responsibilities, each graduate student in our group is tasked with designing an experiment aligned with the course's focus on Green Chemistry, Catalysis, and Solar Energy. This involves creating a comprehensive, step-by-step laboratory procedure, leading day-long instructional sessions, and actively engaging students in hands-on activities. The program also includes a field trip to a local botanical garden, where students explore natural products and their significance in medicine. The overarching aim is to inspire students from various backgrounds to develop enthusiasm for STEM fields. In the summers of 2020 and 2021, the course successfully transitioned to a virtual format, culminating in two publications in the Journal of Chemical Education – one detailing the original version and the other outlining the process of adapting to a fully virtual experience.

Our commitment to community outreach extends to the Females Excelling in More in Math, Engineering, and the Sciences (FEMMES) program. This initiative allows research groups across scientific disciplines at the university to design and lead educational activities for local elementary school-level girls, providing insights into each group's respective research fields. Our graduate students organize a chemistry-focused day filled with engaging demonstrations and activities, such as creating liquid nitrogen ice cream, to introduce basic chemistry concepts in a hands-on and exciting manner. Through active participation in the FEMMES program, our goal is to reach out to young girls in the community, fostering an interest in chemistry and cultivating greater knowledge and confidence in exploring STEM fields.
